description: An edible berry of several species of woody vines in the genus Actinidia. The most common cultivar group of kiwifruit is oval, about the size of a large hen's egg. It has a fibrous, dull greenish-brown skin and bright green or golden flesh with rows of tiny, black, edible seeds.
seasons: Varies by hemisphere; generally late autumn to spring
healthBenefits: Excellent source of Vitamin C, boosting the immune system and skin health.
Rich in Vitamin K, important for blood clotting and bone health.
Good source of dietary fiber, aiding digestion and promoting satiety.
Contains antioxidants and serotonin, which may improve sleep quality.

potentialAllergies.name: Kiwi Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Can cause oral allergy syndrome (itching of mouth, lips, tongue) in sensitive individuals. Contains actinidin, an enzyme that can be an allergen.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Temperate climates with sufficient winter chill. Requires a long growing season.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile, slightly acidic soil (pH 5.5-6.5) rich in organic matter.
3. Propagation: Seeds, cuttings, or grafting. Most commercial kiwis are dioecious (separate male and female plants), requiring both for fruit production.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun on a sturdy trellis or pergola for the vigorous vines.
5. Watering: Requires consistent moisture, especially during the growing season and fruit development.
6. Fertilizing: Apply balanced fertilizer regularly during the growing season.
7. Pruning: Extensive pruning is necessary during dormancy and summer to manage growth and encourage fruiting.
8. Harvesting: Fruits are harvested when firm and mature. They ripen off the vine.
growthDuration: Vines typically start bearing fruit in 3-5 years. Fruit matures in late autumn.
sustainabilityTips: Store kiwis at room temperature to ripen, then refrigerate for longer storage.
Kiwis can be eaten by cutting in half and scooping out the flesh, or by peeling and slicing.
The skin is edible for some varieties if well-washed (and fuzz removed for green kiwis).
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate to high if transported long distances (0.7-1.8 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Kiwi Slices
staticRecipes.description: The simplest way to enjoy the refreshing taste and vibrant color of kiwi.
steps: You can either cut the kiwi in half crosswise and scoop out the flesh with a spoon, or peel the kiwi with a knife or vegetable peeler and then slice it into rounds.
The small black seeds are edible.

staticRecipes.name: Kiwi and Strawberry Smoothie
ingredients: Honey or maple syrup to taste (optional)
steps: Combine chopped kiwi, strawberries, banana (if using), yogurt, and milk/orange juice in a blender.
Taste and add honey or maple syrup if a sweeter smoothie is desired. Blend again briefly.
Pour into a glass and serve immediately.

staticRecipes.name: Kiwi Fruit Salad with Mint and Lime
staticRecipes.description: A refreshing fruit salad where kiwi takes center stage.
ingredients: 3 ripe kiwis, peeled and diced or sliced
1 cup other fruits (e.g., pineapple chunks, grapes, melon balls)
A few fresh mint leaves, chopped
steps: In a medium bowl, gently combine diced/sliced kiwi and other chosen fruits.
In a small bowl, whisk together lime juice and honey (if using).
Drizzle the lime-honey mixture over the fruit salad.
Toss gently to combine. Serve chilled or at room temperature.
